discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
No link lights and the network configuration has been verified would suggest something is disable with the port. If it was only a configuration issue you should still see some link light activity.
B, if your going through the trouble of of connecting the second NIC you should probably configure it first before connecting it to the network.

Selected Answer: C
C looks correct. If you disable your NIC or uninstall it (or if it is corrupted), I believe the light will go out (if you had it on prior). Restarting (A) is part of troubleshooting, B&C would not cause the light to not come on.

Selected Answer: B
Nothing in the question states that the technician has configured the NIC for the "new" network it is getting setup for.

Vague question... as always! My first thoughts are that this would need to be configured... but since "everything on the network is fine"... whatever that means... I would guess that maybe there is port security and to turn that on... also an inference... this question stinks.

questions.question_text:
A technician is connecting a server's secondary NIC to a separate network. The technician connects the cable to the switch but then does not see any link lights on the NIC. The technician confirms there is nothing wrong on the network or with the physical connection. Which of the following should the technician perform
NEXT?

choices.C: Enable the port on the server
choices.B: Configure the network on the server

discussion.content: I think D - the user has to authenticate, usually with 2 MFA, to the authentication server via the SSO platform, which then informs the particular service requested, that the user is authenticated, and the service gives the user access. "Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) is a protocol that enables SSO " - it's not what the user does. https://cloudinfrastructureservices.co.uk/saml-vs-sso-whats-the-difference/

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

comments.content: thank you obi_wan_jacoby your our only hope. lol love the username.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would MOST likely be part of the user authentication process when implementing SAML across multiple applications?
A server administrator needs to check remotely for unnecessary running services across 12 servers. Which of the following tools should the administrator use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Sniffing is the term generally used for traffic monitoring within a network, while port scanning is used to find out information about a remote network. Both sniffing and port scanning have the same objective—to find system vulnerabilities—but they take different approaches.

https://www.informit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=31964#

questions.question_text: A systems administrator is setting up a server on a LAN that uses an address space that follows the RFC 1918 standard. Which of the following IP addresses should the administrator use to be in compliance with the standard?

discussion.content:
RFC 1918 was used to create the standards by which networking equipment assigns IP addresses in a private network. A private network can use a single public IP address. The RFC reserves the following ranges of IP addresses that cannot be routed on the Internet:

10.0.0.0 - 10.255.255.255 (10/8 prefix)
172.16.0.0 - 172.31.255.255 (172.16/12 prefix)
192.168.0.0 - 192.168.255.255 (192.168/16 prefix)

Selected Answer: C
I concur with C
One thing that stood out to me from a context perspective, C is the only private IP address. Could only assume this was referring to private IP addressing haha

questions.question_text: A technician has been asked to check on a SAN. Upon arrival, the technician notices the red LED indicator shows a disk has failed. Which of the following should the technician do NEXT, given the disk is hot swappable?

choices.D: Stop all connections to the volume

discussion.content: Just replace the disk since it's hot swappable

Selected Answer: B
Just to balance Obi_wans realization.
It should be B, the disk is hot-swappable, there's no reason to disrupt any operations.

Selected Answer: B
Easily replace the disk because its hot swappable.

Selected Answer: D
I believe D is correct. You would not want to stop the share (how many shares/printers have been broken this way?). I would stop the connections first, then shut it down (as it cannot be hot swapped in this case) then replace the disk.

comments.content: Well, I should re-read prior to submitting, LOL.. I imagined reading it is NOT hot swappable! When in-fact it says it IS.. My bad, replace disk is correct
